评论概述: Best mechanic pants on the market.
评论详情: As a marine tech these pants are crazy comfortable and dont bind up when getting in tight spaces. They clean up real nice after a day of turning wrenches and wiping grease on them. Getting a few pairs every few months seems reasonable enough. Just buy them you won't regret it.

The leg width is mostly great, not too skinny, except around the thighs, but this would also be solved if they weren’t such a low rise.

评论概述: If you’re looking for something less baggy than even these…
评论详情: Which can still be quite big around the ankle / knee, Dickies makes a slim variety named 573 that they sell primarily in Europe and can be had for cheap on some sites. I returned this pair to buy those instead (trading at an inn???).  The other, ‘skinny’ type listed on Amazon have a small pocket on the back of one thigh (a dealbreaker for most) and are bizarrely skin-tight — not much thought placed into the design of those.  In addition, a certain store stocks a chill store-exclusive baggier but nicely tapered cut (like the kind you used to see on skateboarders in the aughts or ‘90s). Know your options!  573 — just a better version of these “slim / straight” Dickies.

评论概述: Nice on the first wear, but....
类型: Size: 34W x 32LColor: Hunter Green Camo V1
评论详情: These felt great on the first wear: snug, kinda stretchy, made my butt pop, according to the Starbucks barista. The second wear proved them to be like so many other pants whose fabric is cotton, polyester, and spandex. They bag and sag and make you feel dumb for not wearing a belt. And, nope, throwing them back in the wash and a hot dryer doesn't shrink them back to the original fit. Considering this, they are over-priced. So size down. Seriously.

Look cool…feel cool.  Seriously, I don’t think these are meant to be worn in winter.  When Dickies says skinny, they mean it.  I’m slender but have “soccer” legs meaning thicker thighs.  These are snug in the the thigh.  Also, forget wearing with a standard sized, leather belt.  I could only wear with a tactical, webbing style belt.  But, I like em a lot.  They look great tucked into combat boots.  And, I would call them a low rise which is hard to find nowadays.
